metadata.topicName: Satellite Motion as Uniform Circular Motion
metadata.dotPoint: model natural and artificial satellite motion as uniform circular motion

gravity_provides_centripetal.name: Gravity as Centripetal Force
gravity_provides_centripetal.correct: For a satellite in orbit, gravity is the ONLY force acting on it. The gravitational force provides the centripetal force needed for circular motion.

rocket thrust.error: Satellites in stable orbit don't use thrust to stay in orbit.
rocket thrust.fix: Once in orbit, no thrust is needed. Gravity alone keeps the satellite circling.
rocket thrust.action: Think: if rockets were constantly firing, where would the fuel come from?

centrifugal force.error: Centrifugal force is fictitious‚Äînot a real force in an inertial frame.
centrifugal force.fix: The real force is gravity pulling inward (centripetal).
centrifugal force.action: Analyse from an inertial frame: only gravity acts on the satellite.

normal force.error: Satellites aren't in contact with any surface.
normal force.fix: Normal force requires contact. Satellites 'float' with only gravity acting.
normal force.action: Astronauts feel weightless because there's no normal force‚Äîonly free fall.

no force.error: A force IS acting‚Äîgravity. Without it, the satellite would fly off in a straight line.
no force.fix: Gravity constantly pulls the satellite toward Earth, curving its path into a circle.
no force.action: Newton's First Law: circular motion requires a centripetal force.

persistent.gap: You don't understand what force keeps satellites in orbit.
persistent.action: Remember: gravity is the only force on an orbiting satellite. It provides the centripetal force.

orbital_speed_formula.name: Orbital Speed Formula
orbital_speed_formula.correct: Orbital speed depends only on the central body's mass M and the orbital radius r: v = ‚àö(GM/r). It does NOT depend on the satellite's mass.

v = ‚àö(Gm/r).error: Wrong mass. Use the central body's mass M, not satellite mass m.
v = ‚àö(Gm/r).fix: v = ‚àö(GM/r). M is the mass being orbited (e.g., Earth), not the satellite.
v = ‚àö(Gm/r).action: All satellites at the same radius orbit at the same speed, regardless of their mass.

v = GM/r.fix: v = ‚àö(GM/r). The square root comes from equating GMm/r¬≤ = mv¬≤/r.
v = GM/r.action: Check units: ‚àö(GM/r) has units of m/s. GM/r has units of m¬≤/s¬≤.

v = ‚àö(GMr).fix: v = ‚àö(GM/r). Larger radius means slower orbital speed.
v = ‚àö(GMr).action: Distant planets orbit slower than close ones. r in denominator makes sense.

v = ‚àö(Gmr).error: Both mass and position are wrong.
v = ‚àö(Gmr).fix: v = ‚àö(GM/r). Central body's mass M in numerator, radius r in denominator.
v = ‚àö(Gmr).action: The satellite's mass m doesn't appear in the orbital speed formula at all.

persistent.gap: You haven't memorised the orbital speed formula correctly.
persistent.action: Derive it: GMm/r¬≤ = mv¬≤/r. Cancel m, solve for v: v = ‚àö(GM/r).

orbital_period_formula.name: Orbital Period Formula
orbital_period_formula.correct: Orbital period depends on radius cubed and central mass: T = 2œÄ‚àö(r¬≥/GM). Larger orbits have longer periods.

T = 2œÄ‚àö(r/GM).error: Radius should be cubed, not just r.
T = 2œÄ‚àö(r/GM).fix: T = 2œÄ‚àö(r¬≥/GM). The r¬≥ comes from Kepler's Third Law.
T = 2œÄ‚àö(r/GM).action: Kepler's Third Law: T¬≤ ‚àù r¬≥. So T ‚àù ‚àö(r¬≥) = r^(3/2).

T = 2œÄr/v.error: This is correct but not in terms of M and r only.
T = 2œÄr/v.fix: T = 2œÄr/v is valid, but substituting v = ‚àö(GM/r) gives T = 2œÄ‚àö(r¬≥/GM).
T = 2œÄr/v.action: Both formulas are correct. Choose based on what information you have.

T = 2œÄ‚àö(GM/r¬≥).error: Fraction is inverted. r¬≥ should be in numerator.
T = 2œÄ‚àö(GM/r¬≥).fix: T = 2œÄ‚àö(r¬≥/GM). Larger r means longer T.
T = 2œÄ‚àö(GM/r¬≥).action: The Moon takes about 27 days to orbit. It's far away. Closer satellites orbit faster.

T = 2œÄ‚àö(r¬≥/Gm).error: Wrong mass. Use central body's mass M.
T = 2œÄ‚àö(r¬≥/Gm).fix: T = 2œÄ‚àö(r¬≥/GM). The satellite's mass m doesn't affect the period.
T = 2œÄ‚àö(r¬≥/Gm).action: All satellites at the same radius have the same period, regardless of mass.

persistent.gap: You're not clear on the orbital period formula.
persistent.action: Start from 4œÄ¬≤r¬≥ = GMT¬≤. Rearrange to find T = 2œÄ‚àö(r¬≥/GM).

keplers_third_law.name: Kepler's Third Law
keplers_third_law.correct: Kepler's Third Law states that T¬≤ ‚àù r¬≥. For any satellites orbiting the same body, T¬≤/r¬≥ is constant and equals 4œÄ¬≤/GM.

T¬≤ ‚àù r¬≤.error: It's r cubed, not r squared.
T¬≤ ‚àù r¬≤.fix: T¬≤ ‚àù r¬≥. This is Kepler's Third Law.
T¬≤ ‚àù r¬≤.action: Double the radius ‚Üí period increases by factor of 2^(3/2) ‚âà 2.83.

T ‚àù r.error: The relationship is more complex. T¬≤ ‚àù r¬≥.
T ‚àù r.fix: T ‚àù r^(3/2). Taking square root: T = ‚àö(r¬≥) = r^1.5.
T ‚àù r.action: If T ‚àù r, doubling r would double T. Actually, doubling r increases T by ~2.83.

T¬≥ ‚àù r¬≤.action: Remember: 'T squared, r cubed' ‚Äî T¬≤ ‚àù r¬≥.

T¬≤/r¬≥ varies with satellite mass.error: T¬≤/r¬≥ is constant for all satellites orbiting the same body.
T¬≤/r¬≥ varies with satellite mass.fix: T¬≤/r¬≥ = 4œÄ¬≤/GM depends only on the central body's mass M.
T¬≤/r¬≥ varies with satellite mass.action: Satellite mass doesn't matter. A feather and a rocket at same r have same T.

persistent.action: Memorise: T¬≤ ‚àù r¬≥. Practice: if r doubles, by what factor does T change? (2^1.5 ‚âà 2.83)

mass_independence.name: Independence of Satellite Mass
mass_independence.correct: Orbital speed, period, and radius are ALL independent of the satellite's mass. Only the central body's mass M matters.

heavier satellites orbit faster.error: Satellite mass doesn't affect orbital speed.
heavier satellites orbit faster.fix: v = ‚àö(GM/r). The satellite's mass m doesn't appear.
heavier satellites orbit faster.action: A heavy rocket and a light feather at the same radius orbit at the same speed.

heavier satellites need larger orbits.fix: Orbital radius depends on launch conditions, not satellite mass.
heavier satellites need larger orbits.action: The ISS and a tiny cubesat can share the same orbit.

heavier satellites have longer periods.error: Period is independent of satellite mass.
heavier satellites have longer periods.fix: T = 2œÄ‚àö(r¬≥/GM). No m in the formula.
heavier satellites have longer periods.action: All objects at the same orbital radius have the same period.

heavier satellites require more fuel to.error: Once in orbit, no fuel is needed. Gravity does all the work.
heavier satellites require more fuel to.fix: Fuel is needed to GET to orbit, not to stay there.
heavier satellites require more fuel to.action: The Moon has orbited for billions of years without any fuel.

persistent.gap: You think satellite mass affects orbital motion.
persistent.action: In all orbital formulas, the satellite's mass m cancels out. Check: v, T, and a all lack m.

radius_speed_relationship.name: Relationship Between Radius and Speed
radius_speed_relationship.correct: Orbital speed is inversely proportional to the square root of radius. Larger orbits have SLOWER speeds.

larger radius means faster speed.error: Opposite. Larger radius means slower speed.
larger radius means faster speed.fix: v = ‚àö(GM/r). As r increases, v decreases.
larger radius means faster speed.action: Mercury orbits faster than Neptune. Closer planets are faster.

speed is proportional to radius.error: Speed is inversely related to square root of radius.
speed is proportional to radius.fix: v ‚àù 1/‚àör. Double the radius ‚Üí speed decreases by factor of ‚àö2.
speed is proportional to radius.action: Compare: Earth at ~30 km/s, Neptune at ~5 km/s. Further is slower.

speed is independent of radius.fix: v = ‚àö(GM/r). Radius is in the formula.
speed is independent of radius.action: Move a satellite to a higher orbit‚Äîit must slow down to stay in circular orbit.

speed is proportional to r¬≤.fix: v ‚àù 1/‚àör. That's v ‚àù r^(-0.5), not r¬≤.

persistent.gap: You're confused about how orbital speed changes with radius.
persistent.action: Remember: higher orbit = slower speed. v ‚àù 1/‚àör. Practice with planetary data.

radius_period_relationship.name: Relationship Between Radius and Period
radius_period_relationship.correct: Period is proportional to radius to the power 3/2. Larger orbits have LONGER periods.

larger radius means shorter period.error: Opposite. Larger radius means longer period.
larger radius means shorter period.fix: T ‚àù r^(3/2). Distant satellites take longer to complete one orbit.
larger radius means shorter period.action: The Moon takes 27 days. The ISS takes 90 minutes. Moon is further.

period is proportional to radius.error: It's proportional to r^(3/2), not just r.
period is proportional to radius.fix: T ‚àù r^1.5. Double the radius ‚Üí period increases by factor of 2^1.5 ‚âà 2.83.
period is proportional to radius.action: From T¬≤ ‚àù r¬≥, take square root: T ‚àù r^(3/2).

period is inversely proportional to radi.fix: T ‚àù r^(3/2). Further out means longer period.
period is inversely proportional to radi.action: A year on Neptune (far) is 165 Earth years. A year on Mercury (close) is 88 days.

period is proportional to ‚àör.fix: T ‚àù r^1.5. The exponent is 3/2, not 1/2.

persistent.gap: You're confused about how period changes with radius.
persistent.action: Memorise: T ‚àù r^(3/2). Higher orbit = longer period. Calculate T for Earth and Mars.

centripetal_acceleration_orbit.name: Centripetal Acceleration in Orbit
centripetal_acceleration_orbit.correct: Centripetal acceleration in orbit equals v¬≤/r or equivalently GM/r¬≤. This equals the gravitational field strength g at that radius.

a = v/r.fix: a = v¬≤/r. This is the standard centripetal acceleration formula.
a = v/r.action: Check units: (m/s)¬≤/m = m/s¬≤. That's correct for acceleration.

a = GM/r.fix: a = GM/r¬≤. Gravitational field follows inverse square law.
a = GM/r.action: g = GM/r¬≤ is the gravitational field strength at distance r.

a = 0 in orbit.fix: Satellites are constantly accelerating toward Earth. That's why they curve.
a = 0 in orbit.action: Constant velocity ‚â† zero acceleration. Direction changes = acceleration.

a = 9.8 m/s¬≤ always.error: 9.8 m/s¬≤ is only at Earth's surface.
a = 9.8 m/s¬≤ always.fix: a = GM/r¬≤. At higher altitudes, g is less than 9.8 m/s¬≤.
a = 9.8 m/s¬≤ always.action: ISS at 400 km altitude experiences about 8.7 m/s¬≤, not 9.8.

persistent.gap: You're not connecting centripetal acceleration to gravitational field strength.
persistent.action: Key insight: in orbit, centripetal acceleration = gravitational field strength. a = g = GM/r¬≤.

geostationary_conditions.name: Geostationary Orbit Conditions
geostationary_conditions.formula: T = 24 hours, equatorial, same direction as Earth
geostationary_conditions.correct: A geostationary satellite stays above the same point on Earth. Requirements: T = 24 hours, orbit above equator, orbit in same direction as Earth's rotation.

only needs T = 24 hours.error: Period alone isn't sufficient. Position and direction matter too.
only needs T = 24 hours.fix: Also needs: equatorial orbit AND same rotation direction as Earth.
only needs T = 24 hours.action: A 24-hour orbit inclined to equator would trace a figure-8 pattern over Earth.

can orbit over any latitude.error: Must orbit directly above the equator.
can orbit over any latitude.fix: Geostationary satellites are always above the equator.
can orbit over any latitude.action: The orbit plane must match Earth's equatorial plane.

can orbit in either direction.error: Must orbit in the same direction as Earth rotates (west to east).
can orbit in either direction.fix: Orbiting opposite to Earth's rotation wouldn't keep the satellite stationary.
can orbit in either direction.action: Earth rotates west to east. Satellite must too.

any altitude works if T = 24 hours.error: There's only ONE altitude where T = 24 hours.
any altitude works if T = 24 hours.fix: Geostationary altitude is about 36,000 km above Earth's surface.
any altitude works if T = 24 hours.action: T and r are linked: T = 2œÄ‚àö(r¬≥/GM). Only one r gives T = 24 hours.

persistent.gap: You don't fully understand geostationary orbit requirements.
persistent.action: Three conditions: (1) T = 24 hrs, (2) equatorial orbit, (3) west-to-east direction.

geostationary_altitude.name: Geostationary Orbit Altitude
geostationary_altitude.correct: Geostationary orbit is at a specific radius of about 42,200 km from Earth's centre (about 35,800 km above the surface).

any height with T = 24 hours.error: There's only ONE radius that gives T = 24 hours.
any height with T = 24 hours.fix: From T = 2œÄ‚àö(r¬≥/GM), a specific T requires a specific r.
any height with T = 24 hours.action: Calculate: solve 4œÄ¬≤r¬≥ = GMT¬≤ for r with T = 86400 s.

same as ISS altitude.error: ISS is at ~400 km altitude. Geostationary is at ~36,000 km.
same as ISS altitude.fix: Geostationary orbit is about 100 times higher than the ISS.
same as ISS altitude.action: ISS orbits in ~90 minutes. Geostationary takes 24 hours‚Äîmuch further out.

at Earth's surface.error: That's not an orbit‚Äîyou'd be standing on the ground.
at Earth's surface.fix: Geostationary orbit is high: about 36,000 km above the surface.
at Earth's surface.action: Communication satellites are in geostationary orbit, very far from Earth.

about 400 km.error: That's Low Earth Orbit (LEO), not geostationary.
about 400 km.fix: Geostationary altitude is about 36,000 km, not 400 km.
about 400 km.action: Low orbits have short periods (~90 min). Geostationary has T = 24 hours.

persistent.gap: You don't know the geostationary orbit altitude.
persistent.action: Memorise: ~36,000 km above surface, or ~42,000 km from Earth's centre.

weightlessness.name: Weightlessness in Orbit
weightlessness.correct: Astronauts feel weightless because they and their spacecraft are in free fall together. Gravity IS acting‚Äîthey're falling toward Earth but constantly missing it.

no gravity in space.error: Gravity definitely acts on the ISS. It's about 90% of surface gravity.
no gravity in space.fix: At ISS altitude, g ‚âà 8.7 m/s¬≤. Astronauts feel weightless because they're falling.
no gravity in space.action: Calculate g at 400 km altitude. It's definitely not zero.

gravity stops at the atmosphere edge.error: Gravity extends infinitely; it just gets weaker with distance.
gravity stops at the atmosphere edge.fix: g = GM/r¬≤. Never zero, just gets smaller as r increases.
gravity stops at the atmosphere edge.action: The Moon is held by Earth's gravity. The Sun's gravity reaches Pluto.

outside Earth's gravitational field.error: You're never 'outside' a gravitational field. It extends to infinity.
outside Earth's gravitational field.fix: Gravity gets weaker but never disappears completely.
outside Earth's gravitational field.action: Gravitational field has no edge. It follows inverse square law forever.

centrifugal force cancels gravity.error: Centrifugal force is fictitious. The reality is free fall.
centrifugal force cancels gravity.fix: In an inertial frame, only gravity acts. Astronaut and spacecraft fall together.
centrifugal force cancels gravity.action: No normal force ‚Üí nothing pushing on astronaut ‚Üí feels weightless.

persistent.gap: You misunderstand why astronauts feel weightless.
persistent.action: Key insight: they're in free fall. No normal force = no sensation of weight. Gravity is still there.

orbital_radius_measurement.name: Measuring Orbital Radius
orbital_radius_measurement.correct: Orbital radius r is measured from the CENTRE of the planet, not from the surface. r = planet radius + altitude above surface.

altitude above surface.action: ISS at 400 km altitude has r = 6400 + 400 = 6800 km from Earth's centre.

distance to atmosphere.fix: r = distance from centre of planet to centre of satellite.
distance to atmosphere.action: Atmosphere has no sharp boundary anyway.

persistent.gap: You're confusing altitude with orbital radius.
persistent.action: Always remember: orbital formulas use r from the centre. r = R_planet + altitude.

sentences.text: Satellites in polar orbits can observe the entire Earth as it {{d5}} beneath them. These orbits are useful for {{d6}} because they pass over every location.

d5.tooltip: Earth rotates while the satellite's orbital plane stays fixed.

d6.tooltip: Polar orbits cover all latitudes over time.
